chapter.pericope: The Song of Deborah and Barak
chapter.p: 1And Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang on that day:

ul.li1: 2“When long hair hangs loosely in Israel,
ul.li2: when the people willingly offer themselves,
ul.li1: 3Hear, O kings! Give ear, O princes!
ul.li2: I will sing to Yahweh;
I will sing praise to Yahweh,
ul.li1: 4Yahweh, when you went down from Seir,
ul.li2: when you marched from the region of Edom,
ul.li1: the earth trembled, the heavens poured down,
ul.li2: the clouds poured down water.
ul.li1: 5The mountains trembledOr “quaked” before Yahweh,
ul.li2: this Sinai, at the presence of Yahweh, the God of Israel.
ul.li1: 6“In the days of Shamgar son of Anath,
ul.li2: in the days of Jael, the caravans had ceased,
the travelers,Literally “the ones walking on the paths” they kept to the byways.Literally “they went on the crooked roads”
ul.li1: 7The warriorsOthers interpret this word as referring to the “rural dwellers” ceased;
ul.li2: they failed to appear in Israel,
ul.li1: until I,Or “you” Deborah, arose;
ul.li2: IOr “you” arose as a mother in Israel.
ul.li1: 8God chose new leaders,ESV, NRSV translate “when new gods were chosen”
ul.li2: then war was at the gates;
ul.li1: a small shield or a spear was not seen
ul.li2: among forty thousand in Israel.
ul.li1: 9My heart goes out to the commanders of Israel,
ul.li2: those offering themselves willingly among the people;
ul.li1: 10The riders of white female donkeys,
ul.li2: those sitting on saddle blankets,
ul.li3: and those going on the way, talk about it!
ul.li1: 11At the sound of those dividingMeaning uncertain; other translations have “archers” (Tanakh), “musicians” (ESV, NRSV) or “singers” (NIV, HCSB) the sheep
ul.li2: there they will recount the righteous deeds of Yahweh,
the righteous deeds for his warriorsHebrew “warrior” in Israel.
ul.li1: Then the people of Yahweh went down to the gates.
12“Wake up, wake up, Deborah!
ul.li2: Wake up, wake up, sing a song!
ul.li1: Get up, Barak!
ul.li2: Take captive your captives, O son of Abinoam.
ul.li1: 13Then the remnant went down to the nobles;
ul.li2: the people of Yahweh went down for himHebrew “me” against the mighty.
ul.li1: 14From Ephraim is their root into Amalek,
ul.li2: after you, Benjamin, with your family;
ul.li1: from Makir the commanders went down,
ul.li2: and from Zebulun those carrying the scepter
ul.li1: 15And the chiefsHebrew “my chiefs”; ancient translations read “the chiefs” in Issachar were with Deborah;
ul.li2: and Issachar likewise was with Barak;
into the valley he was sent to get him from behind.Literally “he was sent at his feet”
ul.li1: Among the clans of Reuben
ul.li2: were great decisions of the heart.Or “thoughts of the heart”
ul.li1: 16Why do you sit among the sheepfolds,
ul.li2: to hear the calling sounds of the herds?
ul.li1: For the clans of Reuben,
ul.li2: there were great searchings of the heart.
ul.li1: 17Gilead has remainedOr “stayed” beyond the Jordan.
ul.li2: Why did Dan dwell as a foreigner with ships?
ul.li1: Asher sat at the coast of the waters,
ul.li2: and by his coves he has been settling down.
ul.li1: 18Zebulun is a people who scorned death,
ul.li2: and Naphtali, on the heights of the field.
ul.li1: 19“The kings came, they fought;
ul.li2: then the kings of Canaan fought;
ul.li1: at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo,
ul.li2: they got no plunder in silver.
ul.li1: 20The stars fought from heaven;
ul.li2: from their courses they fought against Sisera.
ul.li1: 21The wadiA valley that is dry most of the year, but contains a stream during the rainy season torrent of Kishon swept them away,
ul.li2: the raging wadi torrent,
March on, my soul, with strength!
ul.li1: 22“Then the hooves of the horse beat loudly,
ul.li2: because of galloping, galloping of his stallions.
ul.li1: 23‘Curse Meroz,’ says the angel of Yahweh;
ul.li2: ‘curse bitterly its inhabitants,
ul.li1: because they did not come to the help of Yahweh,
ul.li2: to the help of Yahweh against the mighty.’
ul.li1: 24“Most blessed of women is Jael,
ul.li2: the wife of Heber the Kenite;
ul.li3: most blessed is she of women among tent dwellers.
ul.li1: 25He asked for water, and she gave milk;
ul.li2: in a drinking bowl for nobles, she brought curds.
ul.li1: 26She reached out her hand to the peg,
ul.li2: and her right hand for the workman’s hammer;
ul.li1: and she struck Sisera, crushed his head,
ul.li2: and she shattered and pierced his temple.
ul.li1: 27Between her feet he sank, he fell, he lay.
ul.li2: Between her feet he sank down, he fell;
ul.li3: Where he sank down, there he fell—dead.Literally “devastated”
ul.li1: 28“Through the window she looked down;
ul.li2: the mother of Sisera cried out through the lattice,
ul.li1: ‘Why is his chariot delayed in coming?
ul.li2: Why do the hoof beatsOr “steps” of his chariot tarry?’
ul.li1: 29The wisest of her ladies answer her;
ul.li2: she also answers the question herself:
ul.li1: 30‘Are they not finding and dividing the plunder?
ul.li2: A bedmate or two bedmates for every man;Literally “a womb, two wombs for head of every man”
ul.li1: colorful garments for Sisera,
ul.li2: plunder of colorful garments,Hebrew “garment”
ul.li1: beautifully finished colorful garments,
ul.li2: on the neck of the plunderer?’
ul.li1: 31So may all your enemies perish, O Yahweh,
but those who love him are like the rising sun at its brightest.”

chapter.p: And the land had rest for forty years.
